title: Vacunación contra SARS-CoV-2 y su relación con enfermedad y muerte por COVID-19 en Argentina
abstract: <bold>Objetivo.</bold> Conocer la efectividad de la vacunación contra SARS-CoV-2 para prevenir el desarrollo de enfermedad y muerte por COVID-19 en Córdoba, Argentina, en el periodo enero-junio de 2021. <bold>Métodos.</bold> Se llevó a cabo un estudio de cohorte retrospectivo en 1 139 458 residentes en la provincia de Córdoba. Se construyeron modelos de regresión logística múltiple que relacionaron la vacunación con la infección por SARS-CoV-2 o la muerte por COVID-19, considerando comorbilidades y factores de riesgo de enfermedades crónicas y ajustando por sexo y edad. <bold>Resultados.</bold> El haber recibido una o dos dosis de vacuna en la población general redujo el riesgo de enfermar un 98,8% y 99,3%, respectivamente; y de morir un 83% y 96,5%, respectivamente. En quienes contrajeron COVID-19, la probabilidad de morir se redujo en 57% y 80%, respectivamente. En cuanto a la probabilidad de muerte, el riesgo aumentó a medida que aumentaba la edad y con la pertenencia al sexo masculino o la presencia de obesidad, hipertensión arterial o diabetes mellitus. <bold>Conclusión.</bold> La vacunación es efectiva y protege contra la posibilidad de contraer COVID-19, desarrollar enfermedad grave o morir. Presentar obesidad, hipertensión arterial o diabetes mellitus, en orden decreciente, aumentan el riesgo de morir.

motivations: There is a need to understand the effectiveness of SARS-CoV-2 vaccination in preventing COVID-19 disease and death in Argentina.
objectives: To determine the effectiveness of SARS-CoV-2 vaccination in preventing COVID-19 disease and death in Córdoba, Argentina, between January and June 2021.
methods: A retrospective cohort study was conducted among 1,139,458 residents in Córdoba, Argentina.
Multiple logistic regression models were used to relate vaccination to SARS-CoV-2 infection or COVID-19 death, adjusting for comorbidities, risk factors, sex, and age.
results: Receiving one or two doses of the vaccine significantly reduced the risk of COVID-19 disease and death in the general population.
Vaccination also reduced the probability of death among those who contracted COVID-19.
Age, male sex, obesity, hypertension, and diabetes mellitus were associated with an increased risk of death.
llama_json.research_subject: Effectiveness of SARS-CoV-2 vaccination in preventing COVID-19 disease and death in Argentina

motivations: There is a need to understand the effectiveness of the SARS-CoV-2 vaccination in preventing disease and death from COVID-19 in Córdoba, Argentina.
objectives: To determine the effectiveness of the SARS-CoV-2 vaccination in preventing the development of disease and death from COVID-19 in Córdoba, Argentina, during the period January-June 2021.
methods: A retrospective cohort study was conducted involving residents of the province of Córdoba.

Multiple logistic regression models were constructed to relate vaccination with SARS-CoV-2 infection or death from COVID-19, considering comorbidities and risk factors for chronic diseases and adjusting for sex and age.
results: Receiving one or two doses of the vaccine in the general population reduced the risk of getting sick by 98.8% and 99.3%, respectively, and of dying by 83% and 96.5%, respectively.
In those who contracted COVID-19, the probability of dying was reduced by 57% and 80%, respectively.
The risk of death increased with increasing age and with male sex or the presence of obesity, hypertension or diabetes mellitus.
openai_json.research_subject: Effectiveness of SARS-CoV-2 vaccination in preventing disease and death from COVID-19 in Argentina

motivations: The COVID-19 pandemic has caused significant morbidity and mortality worldwide, necessitating evaluation of vaccine effectiveness in preventing disease and death.
Understanding the real-world effectiveness of SARS-CoV-2 vaccination in specific populations is crucial for public health decision-making.
objectives: Determine the effectiveness of SARS-CoV-2 vaccination in preventing COVID-19 disease and death in Córdoba, Argentina during January-June 2021.
Evaluate the relationship between vaccination status and COVID-19 outcomes while considering comorbidities and chronic disease risk factors.
methods: Conducted a retrospective cohort study analyzing vaccination status and COVID-19 outcomes.
Developed multiple logistic regression models to assess the relationship between vaccination and SARS-CoV-2 infection or COVID-19 death, adjusting for sex, age, and comorbidities.
results: One or two vaccine doses reduced the risk of disease by 98.8% and 99.3% respectively, and the risk of death by 83% and 96.5% respectively.
Among those who contracted COVID-19, vaccination reduced mortality probability by 57% with one dose and 80% with two doses.
Obesity, hypertension, and diabetes mellitus were identified as significant risk factors that increase mortality risk.
anthropic_json.research_subject: SARS-CoV-2 vaccine effectiveness against COVID-19 disease and death in Argentina
